results.title: Watch with mother 2
results.brief_description: A classic collection of five British children’s television programs from the series “Watch with mother” screened to the first children of the television age during the 50s and 60s. Monday - “Picture book: Bush-baby” (transmitted 19 August 1963): Hosted and narrated by Vera McKechnie, along with ‘Sausage’ the dog, (a string puppet) includes a nature segment, animated storytelling and creative activities with a sandbox. Tuesday - “Andy Pandy: The Cart” (transmitted 8 July 1952): Stars string puppet Andy Pandy and his friends and features some real live fluffy ducklings in this short story. Wednesday - “Flower Pot Men: The Potato man” (transmitted 4 October 1953): A combined animated/live action story starring those two very famous puppets who live in flower pots, Bill and Ben. Thursday - “Rag, Tag and Bobtail: Snowballs” (transmitted 25 November 1954): Features hand puppets, Rag the hedgehog, Tag the little mouse and Bobtail the rabbit as they discover the delights of the snowball flower. Friday - “The Woodentops: Horseshoe” (transmitted 14 March 1958): Features the wooden string puppets of the ‘Woodentop’ family - mum, dad, baby, Willie and Jenny the twins, Mrs Scrubit who comes to help the Woodentops, Sam who helps dad, Spotty the dog and Dobbin the horse. These five 15 minute puppet shows are all filmed in b&w and are suitable for pre-schoolers and lower primary school level.

results.title: Watch us move (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Richard Beindorf
results.brief_description: Introduces sensory motor concepts for training preschool retarded children. Discusses a program at a day school, describing the need for sensory integration and demonstrating the effects of the program on the children. Produced by the Child Mental Health Nursing Program UCSF.

results.title: Watch the Gap
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: A sometimes-humorous report on Pine Gap and its strategic use against US military enemies. It also examines the efforts of the Nuclear Disarmament Party to uncover what exactly Pine Gap is being used for. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Watch the birdie
results.brief_description: The secret life of the rarely seen Ungle-Wungle bird. A witty animated skit on birdwatching, set to inexorable and insidiously catchy music.

results.title: Watch over Japan
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Collings and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Australian troops formed part of the Allied occupation forces in Japan after World war II; this film gives us a glimpse of the life of these BCOF men in Japan.

results.title: Watch out for my plant
results.brief_description: A young inner-city boy struggles to grow a plant in a tiny patch of dirt. We see his determination, a special relationship with an older man and the flowering and destruction of the plant. Shows that everyone can do something about his environment, given initiative, responsibility and perseverance. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Wastewater to wood
results.creator_credit: Film Victoria, Streets Ahead Productions and Russ Street
results.brief_description: A short documentary that examines the recycling of waste water for use. This project is one that is being undertaken jointly by the Forest Commission Reclaimed Water Committee and local sewerage authorities.

results.title: Wasted resources
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Katherine Smalley
results.brief_description: Programs to find employment for the mentally retarded have been producing some encouraging results in Canada. Once dubious employers who participated are finding themselves with reliable help. The film shows people employed in a variety of different jobs, and social workers describe the programs they have developed.

results.title: Waste not
results.creator_credit: Robert Dierbeck and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: A survey of the world energy crisis using such examples as the power shortage in the UK in 1973. Workers were put on a three-day week, some pubs and shops reverted to gaslight and a ‘Switch off’ campaign saved 20 percent of power usage. Architects with this in mind start to design energy saving buildings. Wind power and solar panels are discussed and demonstrated. Third world man-power in agriculture is contrasted with the developed world’s high output of farm produce with modern techniques using large energy consuming machines and fertilisers made from petro-chemicals. Narrated by Tom Dunn with camera by Joseph Cabbibo. Also produced by The New York State Education Department and The Ontario Educational Communications Authority.
